data.title: Rectangle, add getPosition returns Vector2
data.body: Created private Vector2 to avoid creating new Vector2 with each call of getPosition method.

data.title: Multi-Page Fonts & Tightly Packed FreeType Glyphs
data.body:
This focuses on two features for bitmap fonts:
- FreeTypeFontGenerator allows the user to specify their own PixmapPacker. This allows for tightly packing many glyphs into a single page.
- BitmapFont, BitmapFontCache, and FreeTypeFontGenerator now support BMFont files with multiple glyphs pages.

As a result, `BitmapFontData.imagePath` and `BitmapFontData.getImagePath()` have been deprecated, and replaced by `imagePaths[]` and `getImagePath(int index)`. Likewise, the same has been done with the `getTextureRegion()` method of FreeTypeBitmapFontData. These could be removed if we're OK with breaking old code. 

Users are encouraged to use `BitmapFont.getRegions()` and the TextureRegion[] constructor for greater compatibility with font files. I did not deprecate `BitmapFont.getRegion()` -- although maybe it should be, for consistency's sake.

See the CHANGES file, as well as FreeTypePackTest and BitmapFontTest. 
## Future Thoughts:

I am currently working on a tool which allows you to specify many BMFont files and TTF files, and it will **tightly** pack all their glyphs into the same texture(s). It then produces a JSON file with details for each FNT (size, name, etc), and ultimately a FontMapper class to facilitate the loading of them. I feel this does not quite belong in the LibGDX codebase; at least not until markup/multi-font text is added to scene2D and BitmapFontCache.

data.title: Bullet: keep reference to MotionState and CollisionShape
data.body:
This change makes btCollisionObject, btRigidBody and btRigidBodyConstructionInfo keep a reference to its MotionState and CollisionShape. So they don't get destroyed by the garbage collector if you don't maintain a reference of your own (which seems a common mistake when using the bullet wrapper). The used btRigidBodyConstructionInfo is not referenced (it doesn't need to outlive the object), only used to pass the reference to the object. Note that the referenced motionstate or collisionshape are not destroyed when the object is destroyed. However the GC will do this eventually, so you can "safely" not keep a reference to them (although I would not recommend that).

I also renamed the getters/setters of btRigidBodyConstructionInfo (e.g. getM_mass() is now getMass()), which slightly breaks backwards compatibility.

data.title: Issue 1558: Unable to Rotate TiledDrawable in Image Actor Patch
data.body: Corrected the bug in Issue 1558. (http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=1558)

data.title: Issue 1451 Patch - Indexes and aliases can now work together
data.body:
I corrected the bug signaled in issue 1451 (http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=1451).

In fact, only the name was stored to remember aliases while the index was also necessary.
I decided to create a new type but to let the code almost the same by overwriting the current rect.index by its aliases indexes. This may be bad if someone decide to use the "rect" variable after the "for".

Also, it will have only a very tiny impact on the running time of the TexturePacker2 tool.

data.title: Bugfixes, simplifications and tests for EarClippingTriangulator
data.body:
I believe this fixes http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=207#c11, http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=1407 and http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=815. Algorithmic changes make infinite loops impossible, and some sort of output will be produced even if the input polygon is degenerate in some way. Also, the implementation is 20% shorter.

I've added a GUI test for the known problematic cases, as well as some other nasty stuff I could come up with, both valid and invalid. Use left and right arrow keys to cycle the polygon vertices.

I have not run any benchmarks, but the order of magnitude should still be the same, if not better: it now only does allocations up front, and does less redundant vertex classification. I did remove the special-casing for convex polygons, but since it was still doing an n^2 thing for those, it shouldn't be a regression.

I've just pushed this code to a production app in the Play Store, and will see how it fares. I think it's already better tested than the old version, but as it's a fairly invasive change, there could be new bugs lurking. I believe merging is safe, but if you'd rather wait until it's been tested in the real world, I can ping this PR if it's proven stable for two weeks, just let me know!

data.title: Array: add Iterable and Iterator.allowRemove
data.body:
Add Array.ArrayIterable: E.g. both the Model and ModelInstance class internally use Array#iterator() a lot, which can lead to usage of nested iterators (note how I worked around that problem in Basic3DSceneTest by iterating on index). This change allows those classes to have an Iterable for internal usage, leaving the Array#iterator() valid for the user to use.

I also added a allowRemove to both ArrayIterator and ArrayIterable. As an example for this, I updated the Material class, where removing attributes using the iterator would make the material (mask) invalid.

data.title: CompositeShader, add unimplemented method to fix warning
BaseShader various changes
data.body:
Add Shader#init() and separate it from the constructor. This allows to easier extend a shader.

Introduce BaseShader#Input:
Input replaces the previous int to identify an uniform/attribute. This allows to extend the Input to add user definable data. It also accepts a Input.Setter which (if set) gets called by default when the uniform needs to be set. This allows to keep the code needed to set an uniform together. Input also has a scope, being either:
- VERTEX_ATTRIBUTE: obviously a vertex attribute, they are added to the public vertexAttributes array
- GLOBAL_UNIFORM: a uniform that only needs to be set once per render pass
- LOCAL_UNIFORM: a uniform that needs to be set for every renderable.

Using an Input in this way is optional, you can still use it to simply reference an uniform (like DefaultShader does). However for a more flexible Shader, it allows to better define who is responsible and when an uniform must be set. I hope to soon PR an improved CompositeShader, which relies on the change.

data.title: Overloading FreeTypeFontGenerator.generateData to support custom PixmapPacker
data.body:
This allows users to pack many glyphs into a single Texture with FreeTypeFontGenerator. The included test example (FreeTypePackTest) packs 2 font styles (regular, italic) each with 5 sizes into a single 1024x512 texture (total of 2,230 glyphs).

NOTES:
- In the future it might be useful to wrap the example into a reusable class, e.g. "FontManager" which handles multiple fonts by style (i.e. font file) and size. 
- Be mindful that each glyph is packed with a name built from pathNameWithoutExtension and size -- if you try to pack a glyph whose alias already exists in the PixmapPacker, you'll get a runtime exception. (I am open to other ideas for generating the alias)
- Idea for future: include BMFont writer for faster subsequent boot times

data.title: Box2dLights (jni version) integration into libgdx
data.body:
Hi!
I just finished some JNI optimisations for box2dLight. The performance are very good!
I also integrate the box2dLight into libgdx in order to have access to box2d's native address.
I tried to not impact libgdx too much but had to add 2 function in src\com\badlogic\gdx\physics\box2d\World.java...

Please tell me if I can do something to make easier the integration into libgdx!

data.title: Bullet & 3D: various
data.body:
This includes https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/pull/469 (Model/ModelInstance common methods) and https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/pull/471 (SoftMeshTest).

Add a convenience constructor to ModelInstance to create a model from a single node and optionally set its transform as modeled (like I manually did in the loading a scene tutorial).

Add a VehicleTest to the bullet tests.

Fix issue 1516. btw Matrix4#scl != Matrix4#scale but Matrix4 lacks Matrix4#scale(Vector3) and Matrix4#scl doesn't have javadocs. How is this intended to distinct?

Add a very basic bullet test not using the BulletEntity class.

Include bullet/extras/serialize, practically allowing to import .bullet files. This allows you to create a whole scene including physics properties within blender/maya, export it to .fbx/.bullet and load it in game. I added a test to show the usage. It also allows to easily create node based animation for kinematics bodies and gpu skinned physics ragdolls (I'll probably add a test to show that later).

Fix and cleanup bullet tests (they didnt properly disposed the models).

Note that bullet/serialize requires std::string, which for android requires STL to be added to application.mk (APP_STL := stlport_static), I couldn't find a way to do that with gdx-jnigen, so I added that manually.

Tested on win64 and android.

My experience on building a bullet scene:
- The default bullet plugin for maya is great for the purpose but doesn't export node names, so its impossible to know which model-node belongs to which bullet body.
- The (walt disney?) opensource maya bullet dynamica plugin is somewhat restricted and requires some customization, but for most scenes it will do
- The blender bullet plugin looks great and by far the best, but since blender uses z-up you must manually rotate the bullet world after importing for y-up.

data.title: Fixed Javadoc in Sound/Music interface + Fixed broken button text in Particle Editor
data.body:
Sound/Music interface:
The descriptions for positive and negative pan values are swapped. Should be "left" for negative, and "right" for positive values, not the other way around.

Particle Editor:
The minimize button of Scaled Numeric Panels show some cryptic characters. Should be a minus ("-") character instead.

data.title: Bullet: reintroduce SoftMeshTest
data.body:
This is a quick fix for SoftMeshTest:
- Add MeshPart support
- Calculate each individual point instead of relying on the mesh provided

This still doesn't update normals. I'll look into that later and then add easier constructors.

data.title: Mesh set* chaining
data.body:
This change makes working with static Mesh objects much, much prettier.

The pattern is used by Wicket and parts of libGDX already

data.title: Model and ModelInstance sync common methods, fix G3dModelLoader
Bullet, update to 2.81
data.body:
This includes https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/pull/462.
- Update Bullet to version 2.81 rev 2613
- Separate the src folder into bullet and custom, the src/bullet folder now contains an exact copy of bullet source, with two exceptions:
- btRaycastVehicle includes some code that swig doesn't like, for the fix see https://github.com/xoppa/libgdx/commit/a33818a7fa227345785e61b14f560e5c6a6a5e00.
- Remove BulletMultiThreaded and MiniCL (which are only useful for PS and XBOX)
- Split the SWIG interfaces into Collision, Dynamics and Softbody.
- Update the build scripts, visual studio project, etc.

What's changed: http://bulletphysics.org/Bullet/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=8490
Tested on win64 and android.

data.title: G3DModelLoader puts a '/' in front of the texture's name
data.body:
I was trying to load a very basic model, with a single texture named "floor.png", and I was getting an exception telling me that it couldn't find the file "/floor.png".

Maybe I missed something important, but I hope it would be useful in case we don't set a material directory at all.

data.title: Fix compile error on GWT, sorry!
data.body: https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/commit/857d63a2153d251d420a32e1ab91d8241c30caab apparently made GWT unhappy. This should make it happier.
